reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 8, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It truly amazes me how much love is in this, how much pain and how real this book feels, I cried multiple times. I love how it represents actual challenges in life and even though I sometimes read books to escape reality, this book made me feel so special, I have no words except that I would definitely recommend it

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Queer British Bake Off at a Magical Boarding School
reviews.reviewText: A short and sweet graphic novel about teens at a magical culinary boarding school with a dash of romance that I just couldn’t help devouring!Reading Basil and Oregano felt like being wrapped in a warm hug from someone that loves and cares for all, is welcoming and supportive just because. The graphic novel included various types of representation including a character using they/them pronouns, toxic complex parents and loving supportive parents, queer relationships, nonbinary and trans characters, a Muslim character, and more. The story expands from not only being a magical boarding school competition to including relatable plots such as feeling pressure to be the best and live up to parents’ expectations, systematic issues in a educational setting, academic burn out and pressures to afford tuition, toxic parental relationships… All seems to be handled well, not being too overwhelming or deep for younger readers to get the message but still enjoy. It was lighthearted, cute and made me hungry for both food and to read more cozy graphic novels. My only complaint is that the conflict ended and were resolved quickly for grudges that seemed to be long-lasting. I would’ve liked more time for the resolutions to play out but I understand this novel is geared towards a younger audience and they may be looking for more of a happy ending and to enjoy the story overall.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: The cooking magic is very pretty but little time is spared for explaining how it works, which is disappointing. The diverse cast is great, though early on it feels like the author had a checklist of what to include. The romance is very cute and the only bullying is wealth/class related, which is a relief with all the diversity afoot.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars What’s not to love?!
reviews.reviewText: This book was absolutely everything I had hoped it would be when I stumbled across it. Witchy lgbtq+ characters where their magic was cooking?!? Count me in! I hope there will be more to follow since I’m officially hooked on these characters!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2023
reviews.reviewText: This graphic novel slaps. A magical cooking school with lots of drama and competition, a sapphic crush plot, and adorable and scary familiars? Yes, and so much more. This is a gem!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars What a cute discovery!
reviews.reviewText: Discovered by chance I bought it because I loved the art style. It was a cute story with magic, friendship, first love and adorable familiars!I loved it and my sons can’t wait to read it too

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Cooking Up A Storm
reviews.reviewText: Melissa Capriglione created the webcomic Falconhyrste, but her latest credit is Basil And Oregano, a family-friendly LGBT manga-styled graphic novel set in a fantasy world. This is essentially Harry Potter mashed up with a cooking show. There is no overarching dark magic villain to vanquish, but more of a look into the characters and their relationships.Porta Bella Magiculinary Academy is a boarding school for talented up and coming cooks where the students use magic. Basil Eyres is a new student who is teamed up with Arabella Oregano, part of an illustrious family of sorcerer cooks. The two are bonded to their new animal familiar, a lovable dog they name Tomato, but they also start having feelings for each other. This gets complicated when Basil learns that Arabella doesn't have any magic talent at all, but it comes solely from an enchanted spoon her mother had. Basil's place in the academy gets endangered too when her scholarship won't kick in if she's not in the top of her class, thus providing trust issues between the two friends, along with a bully discovering Arabella's secret. During their final test, Arabella manages to charm a rampaging dragon, thus earning her in the class with a new scholarship program being set up to accommodate everyone's finances. The story concludes with the two friends solidifying their romantic relationship looking forward to their future together.Basil And Oregano is a charming yuri fairy tale that doesn't need to push the concept of social acceptance down the reader's throat in order to get the message. The single-volume trade paperback confines the story into a slice of life genre that just happens to be set in a fantasy world. It is a little more light-hearted than you would expect from a plot involving teenagers discovering their magic potential, even if it is simply for culinary arts. This young adult novel makes for a decent read and reminiscent to otaku of past shoujo-ai manga.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Sweetest book I've read
reviews.reviewText: I loved the colorful and diverse aesthetic of this graphic novel, and I also love the character development of the antagonist as well. Basil and Oregano are a beautiful and sweet couple.
